The "Ronald Reagan Centennial Commission Act" establishes a commission to honor Ronald Reagan on the 100th anniversary of his birth. The Commission will plan and carry out activities, provide advice to government agencies and civic groups, and develop activities for the Federal Government to honor Reagan. The "Ronald Reagan Centennial Commission Act" establishes a commission to honor Ronald Reagan on the 100th anniversary of his birth. The Commission will be composed of 11 members, including government officials and appointees recommended by the Ronald Reagan Foundation. The Archivist of the United States serves on the Commission in an ex officio capacity to provide advice. Each member is appointed for the life of the Commission, with appointments to be made within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission appoints an executive director and necessary staff to perform duties, with appointments made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The executive director and staff may be appointed without following certain civil service laws. The Commission appoints an executive director and staff to perform duties, exempt from certain civil service laws. The Secretary of the Interior or the Archivist of the United States may detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission can also procure temporary services and accept volunteer services. The Commission may accept voluntary and uncompensated services as necessary. It has the power to hold hearings, use the United States mails, and obtain official data from other government departments or agencies. The Commission can receive gifts, solicit donations, and use government facilities for its work. It also has the authority to enter into contracts to fulfill its duties. Additionally, the Commission is required to submit annual reports on revenue and expenditures to the President and Congress. The Commission is mandated to submit annual reports on revenue and expenditures, including gifts over $250, with donor details. Interim reports can be submitted as needed, with a final report due by April 30, 2011, containing activities summary, financial accounting, findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission can terminate after submitting the final report but no later than May 30, 2011. An annual audit is also required. SEC. 9. ANNUAL AUDIT.
The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior may perform an audit of the Commission, make the results available to the public, and transmit them to specific committees.
SEC. 10. PROHIBITION ON OBLIGATION OF FEDERAL FUNDS.
